lesson.title: So many students are walking around
lesson.focus:
How to describe something happening right now
Verb tense: Present continuous tense
lesson.backstory: It's Pailin and Chloe's first day of school at UCLA! Pailin has already had her first class, East Asian Art, and now she's walking with Chloe to their next class, The Anthropology of Art.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Wow, so many students are walking around. I love it.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Me too. What are you doing after class?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I'm meeting Luke for lunch. Do you want to join?

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Yeah! Oh look, are they giving out free coffee?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, they are. Do you want one?

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Sure! But let's hurry, we're running late to class.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Oh, wait Chloe. We aren't going the right way! Our class is the other way! …

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Wow, we're on time!

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Pai, is your phone ringing? Turn it off, the professor is walking in right now!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Sorry, I'm turning it off!

comprehension_questions.prompt: What is Pailin doing after class?
options: B. She's studying at the library.
C. She's meeting Luke for lunch.
D. She's going to her next class.

comprehension_questions.prompt: What are some students giving out for free?
Were Pailin and Chloe late or on time for their class?

practice_exercises.title: QUICK PRACTICE
practice_exercises.prompt: Fill in the blanks with the present continuous verb structure. Use contractions when possible.

items.text: It ______ [rain] outside.

practice_exercises.title: QUICK PRACTICE
practice_exercises.prompt: Fill in the blanks with the negative present continuous verb structure. Use contractions when possible.

items.text: Chloe and Alex ______ [date].

practice_exercises.title: QUICK PRACTICE
practice_exercises.prompt: Turn these affirmative present continuous sentences into questions.

items.text: She’s crying.
You’re writing a letter.
Dara is studying at the library.

practice_exercises.title: PRACTICE AFFIRMATIVE SENTENCES
practice_exercises.prompt: Change the following sentences from present simple tense to present continuous tense.

items.text: I eat breakfast.
They play soccer.
He watches TV.
Sylvie talks on the phone.
My mom and grandma cook dinner.
items.answer: my mom and grandma are cooking

practice_exercises.title: PRACTICE NEGATIVE SENTENCES
practice_exercises.prompt: Change the affirmative sentences into negative sentences.

items.text: She's drinking tea.
items.answer: shes not drinking, she isnt drinking

items.text: It's snowing outside.
items.answer: its not snowing, it isnt snowing

items.text: I'm talking on the phone.
My brother and sister are taking the train.
items.answer: my brother and sister are not taking, my brother and sister arent taking

items.text: We're studying for our exam.
items.answer: were not studying, we arent studying

practice_exercises.title: PRACTICE MAKING QUESTIONS
practice_exercises.prompt: Change the sentences into questions.

items.text: Dara is doing the dishes.
The trains are running late.
They're driving to the mall.
He's taking a shower.
You're typing on the computer.

practice_exercises.title: CORRECT OR INCORRECT
practice_exercises.prompt: Determine if the grammar of the present continuous tense sentences is correct or not. If incorrect, enter the correct sentence into the box.

items.text: I cooking lunch.
Is you wearing a jacket?
You not listening to me.
items.answer: you are not listening, you arent listening

items.text: He's drive to work.
They watching TV.

practice_exercises.title: PRESENT CONTINUOUS VS. PRESENT SIMPLE TENSE
practice_exercises.prompt: Determine if the sentence should use present continuous tense or present simple tense, based on the context clues in the sentence.

options: A. She's going to the gym every morning.
B. She goes to the gym every morning.
A. I'm not knowing the answer.
B. I don't know the answer.
A. Are you visiting Thailand every year?
B. Do you visit Thailand every year?
A. We're watching a movie now.
B. We watch a movie now.

practice_exercises.title: OPEN-ENDED PRACTICE
practice_exercises.prompt: Answer the following questions using present continuous tense. You can make up an answer - the point is to practice using this verb tense.

items.text: Where are you sitting right now?
What are you drinking right now?
What is your best friend doing right now?
What are you doing tonight? Click here for more present continuous tense exercises.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to describe something happening right now
Verb tense: Present continuous tense
## PRESENT CONTINUOUS TENSE
Present continuous tense is the verb tense used to talk about something happening right now.
Take a look at these lines from the conversation:
So many students are walking around.
We’re running late to class.
The professor is walking in right now!
I’m turning it off!
Present continuous tense to describe the present moment
These sentences all describe actions happening at the moment of speaking. While Pailin is walking on the school campus with Chloe, she looks around and says:
So many students are walking around.
She's describing what she sees at that moment. She's not talking about a regular occurrence or something in the past or future.
Present continuous tense vs. present simple tense
Compare these two sentences:
We’re running late to class. (present continuous tense)
At this moment, it looks like Pailin and Chloe will be late to class.
We run late to class. (present simple tense, Lesson 2.3)
Chloe could say this if she and Pailin are often late to class, as this would demonstrate a routine or habit.
## AFFIRMATIVE SENTENCE STRUCTURE
Take a look at this line from the conversation:
I’m turning it off!
Compare its structure to this sentence in present simple tense:
I turn it off.
Notice the differences
What differences do you notice?
There is a ‘to-be’ verb between the subject and verb
Add -ing to the verb
These rules apply to all sentences using present continuous tense.
Contractions
Remember that the to-be verb is usually contracted to the subject, as in ‘I’m’ or ‘She’s.’
Present continuous tense - Affirmative sentences
Here is the structure of affirmative present continuous sentences. Note that contractions are used when possible.
## TABLE-1:
## TABLE-1:
## QUICK PRACTICE
## ITEM: 1
## ITEM: 2
## ITEM: 3
## NEGATIVE SENTENCES
Negative sentences in present continuous tense show that something is not happening right now, as in this line from the conversation:
We aren’t going the right way!
The negative to-be verb ‘aren’t’ makes the sentence negative.
Contractions
Remember that ‘are not’ and ‘is not’ can be contracted in two ways. So, the sentence above could also be ‘We’re not going the right way!’
Present continuous tense vs. present simple tense
Compare the following two sentences to see how present continuous tense and present simple tense change the meaning of a sentence:
Pailin isn’t driving to school. (present continuous tense)
This means that right now, she isn’t driving to school, but is doing something else. Maybe she usually drives to school, but right now she’s taking the bus instead, or is walking to school.
Pailin doesn’t drive to school. (present simple tense, Lesson 2.3)
In contrast, this means that Pailin never drives to school. It describes a routine or habit that doesn’t happen.
Present continuous tense - Negative sentences
Here’s the structure for negative present continuous sentences. Note that contractions are used in all the sentences.
## TABLE-2:
## TABLE-2:
## QUICK PRACTICE
## ITEM: 1
## ITEM: 2
## ITEM: 3
## MAKING QUESTIONS
Take a look at these present continuous questions from the conversation:
Are they giving out free coffee?
Is your phone ringing?
These are questions about the present moment.
Present continuous tense vs. present simple tense
Compare the first line to this present simple tense question:
Do they give out free coffee?
This asks if the students regularly give out free coffee, not if they’re doing it at this exact moment.
Present continuous tense - Questions
Here’s the structure for present continuous questions. Simply switch the position of the subject and to-be verb to make it a question.
## TABLE-3:
## TABLE-3:
## QUICK PRACTICE
## IRREGULAR SPELLING RULES
You can simply add -ing to most verbs. But there are a few other spelling changes to remember:
Verbs ending in a silent -e:
Drop the -e before adding -ing
make → making
write → writing
Verbs ending in 1 vowel + 1 consonant (letters that aren’t vowels):
Double the consonant before adding -ing
run → running
stop → stopping
get → getting
Verbs ending in -ie:
Change the -ie to -y before adding -ing
lie → lying
die → dying

sections.content:
## PRESENT CONTINUOUS TENSE TO TALK ABOUT THE FUTURE
Present continuous tense is used for things that are happening right now. But this tense can also be used in another important way:
Present continuous tense is also used for arranged plans in the future.
Arranged plans
Take a look at this exchange from the conversation:
Chloe: What are you doing after class?
Pailin: I’m meeting Luke for lunch.
Notice that Chloe isn’t asking what Pailin is doing now, but rather after class, which is in the future. Then, Pailin says that she’s meeting Luke for lunch, which will happen after class.
Before the moment of speaking, Luke and Pailin already agreed to meet for lunch, so this is an arranged plan.
Examples
Here are more examples, with time markers to indicate that these things will happen in the future:
We’re going to Europe in two weeks.
What’re you doing next week?
Mark is meeting me at 8 for dinner.
I’m not working this weekend.
Present continuous tense vs. future simple tense
You’re probably wondering why you wouldn’t use ‘will’ in these sentences and questions, since ‘will’ is used for the future.
There is a subtle difference between using future simple tense and present continuous tense for the future:
Future simple tense (will):
Used for spontaneous decisions or plans made at the moment of speaking. Think of it as a plan that’s still somewhat flexible.
I’ll visit Thailand when I can take time off work.
This is a general dream or intention - no preparations have been made.
Present continuous tense:
Used for fixed plans where preparations have already been made and agreed upon before the moment of speaking.
I’m visiting Thailand next month.
Your flight has been booked and plans have been arranged already.
Don’t stress if you’re confused! People will still understand you if you use future simple tense for future plans.
Just note that it’s more common and casual to use present continuous tense in those instances.
## SHORT FORM ANSWERS
Remember that you can answer yes/no questions with a simple ‘Yes’ or ‘No,’ but short form answers can help maintain the flow of a conversation.
To answer present continuous tense questions:
- Use the to-be verbs ‘am · are · is’ in ‘yes’ answers
- Use negative to-be verbs ‘am not · aren’t · isn’t’ in ‘no’ answers
Example from the conversation
Notice how Pailin answers Chloe's question in the conversation:
Chloe: Are they giving out free coffee?
Pailin: Yeah, they are.
Don’t contract the to-be verb
Also take note that ‘they are’ should not be contracted to ‘they’re’ in the case of these short form answers.
Examples
Luke: Is Emily doing laundry?
Pailin: Yeah, she is.
Luke: Are you driving to work?
Pailin: Yeah, I am.
Luke: Are they swimming in the lake?
Pailin: No, they aren’t. (or ‘No, they’re not.’)
Luke: Is the microwave working?
Pailin: No, it’s not. (or ‘No, it isn’t.’)

sections.content:
## MISTAKE #1 - SUPER COMMON MISTAKE!!
Thai students often mix up the grammar of present simple tense and present continuous tense.
Incorrect sentences
I watching TV now. [X]
The to-be verb is omitted.
I’m watch TV now. [X]
There is no -ing on the main verb.
Correct sentence
I’m watching TV now. [✓]
‘To-be’ verb + ‘-ing’ verb
Remember that a to-be verb must always be paired with an -ing verb when using present continuous tense.
## MISTAKE #2 - SUPER COMMON MISTAKE!!
Similarly, with negative present continuous tense sentences, Thai students often say the following sentences incorrectly:
I not drinking coffee. [X]
She not working right now. [X]
Don’t forget to use the to-be verb in these sentences.
Correct sentences
I’m not drinking coffee. [✓]
She’s not working right now. (or ‘She isn’t working right now.’) [✓]
## MISTAKE #3
Thai students often answer yes/no present continuous questions incorrectly:
Pailin: Is Eric sleeping?
Luke: Yeah, he sleeping. [X]
Pailin: Are you driving?
Luke: Yes, I driving. [X]
Pailin: Is she shopping?
Luke: No, she not. [X]
Remember, your short answer must have a to-be verb, not the main verb.
Correct responses
Pailin: Is Eric sleeping?
Luke: Yeah, he is. [✓]
Pailin: Are you driving?
Luke: Yeah, I am. [✓]
Pailin: Is she shopping?
Luke: No, she isn’t. (or ‘No, she’s not.’) [✓]

lesson.title: Where is Powell Library?
lesson.backstory: It's Pailin's first day of school at UCLA. She's not sure where some buildings are on campus, so she asks a student walking by for help.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Excuse me, where's Powell Library?

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Oh, it's nearby. Walk straight down this path, past the garden. At the first intersection, turn left. It's the huge building next to the fountain.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay, thank you so much! Oh, and where's Perloff Hall? My next class is there.

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Oh, that's a little far. Walk down this path, and keep going straight for 3 blocks. Then turn right at the lights. It's a gray building across from the basketball stadium.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Cool, so walk straight for three blocks, then turn left?

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: No no, turn right at the lights.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Got it, thank you so much!

What is Perloff Hall across from?
options: A. It's across from a garden.
B. It's across from the library.
C. It's across from the basketball stadium.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to give directions
WHERE’S + PLACE?
In the conversation, Pailin asks:
Excuse me, where’s Powell Library?
Where’s Perloff Hall?
Structure
To ask where a place is, use this structure:
Where’s [place]?
Where’s = Where is
Excuse me
When asking a stranger for directions, saying ‘Excuse me’ is a polite way to get their attention, as Pailin said to the student walking by.
More examples
Here are more questions Pailin might ask as she finds her way around the school campus:
Where’s the restroom?
Where’s the bookstore?
Where’s the gym?
Where’s the parking lot?
Where’s the bus stop?
## PREPOSITIONS FOR GIVING DIRECTIONS
In the conversation, the student gives Pailin directions to both Powell Library and Perloff Hall. Look at the prepositions he uses in his directions:
Oh, it’s nearby.
Walk past the garden.
It's the huge building next to the fountain.
It’s a gray building across from the basketball stadium.
As you can see, prepositions help understand where things are in relation to each other.
Common prepositions for directions
Here are some common prepositions used when giving or receiving directions:
[is] in front of [a place]
The parking lot is in front of the hospital.
[is] next to [a place]
The pharmacy is next to the grocery store.
[is] across from [a place]
The park is across from the museum.
[is] by [a place]
The restaurant is by the river.
[is] near [a place] · [is] close to [a place]
My house is near the bus stop.
The store is close to my apartment.
[is] nearby
The gas station is nearby.
[is] on the left
The bookstore is on the left.
[is] on the right
The movie theater is on the right.
[is] on the corner
The gas station is on the corner.
[verb] past [a place]
Drive past the bank, then turn right.
Walk past the park, and the coffee shop is on your left.
[verb] down [the street · the sidewalk · the path]
Drive down this street for two blocks, then turn right.
Walk down the sidewalk until you see the theater on the corner.
To-be verbs
The verb ‘is’ can be replaced with other to-be verbs, like ‘am,’ ‘are,’ ‘was,’ or ‘were,’ depending on the subject and verb tense.
## TERMS FOR GIVING DIRECTIONS
When the student directs Pailin to Powell Library and Perloff Hall, he says:
Walk straight down this path.
At the first intersection, turn left.
Keep going straight for 3 blocks.
Then turn right at the lights.
Common nouns and verbs for directions
He uses precise verbs and location markers to give accurate directions. The most common ones are below:
go straight · walk straight · drive straight
Go straight for three blocks.
Walk straight until you see the park.
Drive straight for two miles.
keep going
After you turn right, keep going straight until you see the bridge.
turn left
Turn left at the next corner.
turn right
Turn right after the church.
the traffic light · the lights
After you pass the traffic light, the store will be on your right.
Turn left at the lights.
the intersection
Turn left at the intersection.
the stop sign
Turn right at the stop sign.
[#] blocks
The subway station is only two blocks away.
Quick tip!
Do you struggle to remember which way is ‘left’ and ‘right’? A helpful trick is that your left hand makes an ‘L’ shape with the thumb and forefinger!
## PUTTING IT TOGETHER
By combining the prepositions and terms above, you can give and understand directions to nearly any place. Notice how directions are given to these places based on the maps: Need to make graphics for these
Driving directions from the store to the hospital:
Drive straight down this road.
At the second intersection, turn right.
Keep going straight for about five minutes.
Then, you’ll see the hospital on your left.
Walking directions from the subway station to the library:
Turn left when you exit the station, and walk straight for four blocks.
The library will be on the corner of the intersection, across from Starbucks.

lesson.title: 7th floor, please
lesson.backstory: It's Pailin's first week of school at UCLA. She's stepping into an elevator to go to her class, when another student in the elevator starts a conversation with her.

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Which floor?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: 7th floor, please.

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Are you an exchange student here too?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yep!

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Me too! I'm from Germany. Where are you from?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I’m from Thailand.

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Cool! I’m going to travel to Thailand on October 5th, for my brother’s 18th birthday.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Awesome! I hope you guys like it there.

transcript.speaker: Man
transcript.line_text: Thanks. Is this your first time in America?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: No, it’s my second time. I came last year for my sister’s wedding. Her husband is American.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use ordinal numbers
## ORDINAL NUMBERS
Imagine you won a race. Woohoo! Congratulations!
You can’t say that you came in ‘one’ place. Rather, you’d say you came in ‘first’ place. That’s an ordinal number.
Meaning of ‘ordinal number’
Ordinal numbers show the position or order of something, not the quantity.
Meaning of ‘cardinal number’
Cardinal numbers show quantity, like ‘two’ or ‘five.’
## DATES
Ordinal numbers are used for saying the date.
In the conversation, the man says to Pailin:
I’m going to travel to Thailand on October 5th (fifth).
It would sound awkward if he said ‘on October 5 (five).’
‘The’ before a date
When you omit the month from the sentence, ‘the’ must come before the ordinal number. For example:
My birthday is on the 4th (fourth).
Next Tuesday is the 21st (twenty-first).
## SEQUENCE OR ORDER
Ordinal numbers are used to show the position of something in a sequence or order.
Take a look at these lines from the conversation:
Man: Is this your first (1st) time in America?
Pailin: No, it’s my second (2nd) time. I came last year for my sister’s wedding.
Pailin is not saying that she has been to America two times. She’s saying that this is her second visit, showing the order of her trips.
Examples of ordinal numbers showing a sequence or order
Tyler came in second (2nd) place in the race.
This is my fifth (5th) time in Japan.
I’m the third (3rd) person in line.
I like the second (2nd) dress more than the first (1st) one.
The first (1st) step is to preheat the oven.
## FLOORS OF A BUILDING
Ordinal numbers are used to show the position of a floor within a building.
In the conversation, Pailin says to the man:
7th (seventh) floor, please.
This is different from saying how many floors a building has. Cardinal numbers (1, 2, 3…) would be used for this, for example:
My apartment has 11 floors.
‘The’ before the floor number
Take note that ‘the’ usually comes before the ordinal number when referring to a building floor, for example:
I live on the 11th floor.
The rooftop restaurant is on the 30th floor.
## BIRTHDAYS OR ANNIVERSARIES
Ordinal numbers are used to show which birthday or anniversary you are celebrating.
In the conversation, the man tells Pailin:
I’m going to travel to Thailand on October 5th, for my brother’s 18th (eighteenth) birthday.
He is telling Pailin which birthday they will be celebrating, not how many years old his brother is.
Ordinal numbers vs. cardinal numbers
Tomorrow is our 50th (fiftieth) wedding anniversary. (ordinal number)
We’ve been married for 50 years. (cardinal number)
There are more situations where ordinal numbers are used, but the above ways are the most common.
## ORDINAL NUMBER STRUCTURE
You may have noticed that making ordinal numbers is more complex in English than it is in Thai. Unfortunately, there's no trick or rule to remember the names of ordinal numbers. You simply have to memorize them.
Word endings
Most ordinal numbers are simply the cardinal number with -th added to the end, but not all of them.
Pronunciation changes
It’s also important to notice how the pronunciation changes between a cardinal and ordinal number.
Ordinal number structure
Here is a chart of ordinal numbers. The * means that the ordinal number is quite different from the cardinal number:
## TABLE-4:
## TABLE-4:
## FUN FACT
Do you know what ESL stands for? It stands for English-as-a-2nd-language. Your first language is Thai, while English is your second language [or maybe it’s your third or fourth language!].

Thai people often mistakenly assume that every short-form ordinal number ends in ‘-th.’ Notice the incorrect and correct ways to write these ordinal numbers:
31th [X]

Also keep in mind that 11th, 12th, and 13th end in -th.

sections.content:
## SMALL TALK
Small talk is super common in the US, and it’s one of the first things tourists notice. Small talk occurs in everyday situations, like when you're in line, on the elevator, or chatting with a cashier. It's usually about light topics, like the weather or what's going on around you.
For example, at the airport, someone might ask, ‘First time in Japan?’ or ‘This line's long, huh?’ You've probably noticed some westerners doing this in Thailand. Even if you’re a shy person, it's great English practice!

lesson.title: Skylight Books is hiring
lesson.focus:
How to use ‘if’ for real possibilities
(First conditionals)
lesson.backstory: Pailin is having lunch on the UCLA campus with her host brother Luke, who is also a student there.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Pailin, do you want a part-time job?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yes! I'm going to look for a job this week.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: My friend works at Skylight Books, and they're hiring. If you want to work there, I can tell him.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Oh my God, yes! I would love to work at a bookstore.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Okay. I'm messaging him now...He said if you're free, you can come in this week for an interview.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: My classes finish at 2, so I'm free after that.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Okay, can you go there at 3 on Thursday for an interview?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: That's perfect.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: If I'm not working that day, I can take you to your interview.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Thank you! If you can't, no worries. I'll take the bus. Wow, if I get the job, I'll get discounts on books!

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use ‘if’
## ‘IF’ CREATES CONDITIONS
The word ‘if’ is a conjunction word used to describe something that might happen when a certain condition is met. It sets up a condition that must happen for something else to happen or be possible.
Example
Take a look at this line from the conversation:
If I get the job, I’ll get discounts on books!
This means you'll get discounts on books ONLY IF you get the job. No job? No discounts.
Structure
If [the condition], [the result].
The condition = I get the job
The result = I’ll get discounts on books
More examples from the conversation
If you want to work there, I can tell him.
If you're free, you can come in this week for an interview.
If I'm not working that day, I can take you to your interview.
If you can't, no worries.
Flipping the structure
The structure can be also flipped with no change to the core meaning of the sentence:
[The result] if [the condition].
So, the lines above can also be:
I’ll get discounts on books if I get the job.
The result = I’ll get discounts on book
The condition = I get the job
I can tell him if you want to work there.
You can come in this week for an interview if you’re free.
I can take you to your interview if I’m not working that day.
No worries if you can’t.
## VERB TENSES IN ‘IF’ STATEMENTS
Although the sentence structure of ‘if’ statements is simple, the verb tenses of the condition and the result can vary. They can use the affirmative or negative verb structure, and they can be questions, too.
If [present simple tense], [result with ‘will’].
This structure implies that an outcome is certain if something happens.
If I get the job, I’ll get discounts on books!
If they don’t leave soon, they’ll miss their flight.
If you tell the truth, I won’t be angry. (won’t = will not)
If it rains, will the event be canceled?
If [present simple tense], [result with ‘can’].
This structure implies that an outcome is possible if something happens.
If you want to work there, I can tell him.
If you’re free, you can come in this week for an interview.
If you don’t have a ticket, you can’t enter.
If you’re not busy, can you review my résumé?
If [condition with ‘can’], [result with ‘will’].
This structure implies that having the ability to do something will lead to a future result.
If you can speak Spanish, you’ll have more job opportunities.
If you can give me a ride to the airport, I’ll pay for your gas.
If you can’t, no worries.
This line from the conversation is an abbreviated and informal way of saying ‘If you can’t give me a ride to the interview, it won’t be a problem.’
Present continuous tense for the future
This line from the conversation has a slightly nuanced structure:
If [present continuous tense], [result with ‘can’].
If I’m not working that day, I can take you to your interview.
Note that ‘I’m not working that day’ is not used to describe something happening now, but describes a planned future event.
It’s like saying ‘If I don’t work that day, I can take you to your interview.’
Flipping the structure
Remember that the sentence structure of the above ‘if’ conditionals can be swapped without any change to the meaning.
So, some examples from above could become:
I won’t be angry if you tell the truth.
Will the event be canceled if it rains?
You can’t enter if you don’t have a ticket.
Can you review my résumé if you’re not busy?
You’ll have more job opportunities if you can speak Spanish.
## FIRST CONDITIONALS
The grammar structure using ‘if’ that you learned above is called a ‘first conditional’ sentence. They’re used to express real possibilities for particular situations that are likely to happen in the future.
Later, you will learn about ‘second conditionals’ and ‘third conditionals,’ which describe hypothetical situations. Those have an even more complex grammar structure than first conditionals.

sections.content:
## IF NOT
‘If not’ is a useful phrase that substitutes a negative condition, especially when it directly follows a question.
Example
Can you help me? If not, I’ll ask someone else.
This is a more concise way of saying:
Can you help me? If you can’t help me, I’ll ask someone else.
‘If not’ substitutes ‘If you can’t help me.’
More examples
Did you buy milk yesterday? If not, I’ll stop by the store to get some.
Do you have any plans for tonight? If not, we could go to the movies.
Did you feed the cat? If not, I’ll do it now.
If not, no worries
The phrases ‘If not, no worries’ or ‘If not, it’s okay’ are common ways to soften a request and avoid putting pressure on the person you’re asking a favor from.
Can you pick up some paper plates? If not, no worries. I can also ask Luke to get some.
## ZERO CONDITIONALS
‘Zero conditionals’ express habits, general truths, or facts. They describe general situations (not a particular situation) where one thing always leads to another. They express certainty - there is no doubt about the outcome.
Structure
If [present simple tense], [present simple tense].
[Present simple tense] if [present simple tense].
If I drink coffee at night, I don’t sleep well.
I work overtime if I have a lot of work to finish.
When = if
In these instances, the conjunction ‘when’ is interchangeable with ‘if,’ so the sentences can be:
When I drink coffee at night, I don’t sleep well.
I work overtime when I have a lot of work to finish.
Zero conditions vs. first conditionals
First conditionals are different from zero conditionals in this way:
Zero conditionals: Used for situations that are certain to happen.
First conditionals: Used for situations that are likely to happen. You will use first conditionals much more often than zero conditionals.

lesson.backstory: Pailin is having dinner on the UCLA campus with her friend Chloe, who is also a student at UCLA.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Wow, that meal was so good, but it was kind of expensive!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, the food in LA is good but expensive.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Speaking of money, did you apply for that job at the bookstore?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yep! I have an interview on Thursday at 3.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Nice! Is the interview at Skylight Books or Borders?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: It’s at Skylight, the one on Wilshire Boulevard.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Oh good, that’s near UCLA. Do you have classes on that day?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I do. My classes finish at 2.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use the prepositions 'at, on, in' for time and place
## ‘AT’ VS. ‘ON’ VS. ‘IN’
Recall that prepositions are words that show the relationship of where and when things occur.
The words ‘at · on · in’ are often used to indicate time and place. Thai and English sometimes use prepositions differently, so you can't always translate them directly.
An easy way to remember when to use these three prepositions for time and place is with this pyramid: Need to make graphic
At = used for the most specific locations and times
On = used for less specific locations and times
In = used for very general locations and times
## ‘AT’ FOR PLACE & TIME
The preposition ‘at’ is used for giving specific locations and times.
‘At’ for specific places
In the conversation, Chloe asks Pailin:
Did you apply for that job at the bookstore?
Is the interview at Skylight Books or Borders?
Chloe names specific places, like the ‘bookstore’ and ‘Skylight Books.’
‘At’ usually comes before an address or a specific point like ‘the mall’ or ‘the bank.’
More examples of ‘at’ for specific places
I’m at home right now.
He’s standing at the bus stop.
Meet us at 123 Main Street.
The party is at my friend’s house.
‘At’ for specific times
‘At’ is also used for specific times.
In the conversation, Pailin says:
I have an interview on Thursday at 3.
My classes finish at 2.
She isn’t referring to a day of the week or a month, but rather an exact time, so ‘at’ must be used.
More examples of ‘at’ for specific times
I wake up at 7:15 every morning.
The store closes at 5:30PM.
Let’s meet at noon.
## ‘ON’ FOR PLACE & TIME
The preposition ‘on’ is used for times and places that are less specific than ‘at,’ and more specific than ‘in.’
‘On’ for streets and surfaces
In the conversation, Pailin tells Chloe about her upcoming job interview:
It’s at Skylight, the one on Wilshire Boulevard.
Pailin says the bookstore is ‘on Wilshire Boulevard,’ which is the name of a big road.
‘On’ is used for streets, floors, public transportation, and surfaces.
Examples of ‘on’ for streets and surfaces
My office is on the 7th floor. (‘on’ comes before the floor number)
I live on a quiet street. (‘on’ comes before a street)
I’m on the subway right now. (‘on’ comes before public transportation)
The book is on the table. (‘on’ comes before a surface)
I want to live on an island. (‘on’ comes before a surface)
‘On’ for days and dates
For time, ‘on’ comes before days of the week, dates, and holidays.
In the conversation, Pailin says this:
I have an interview on Thursday at 3.
‘Thursday’ is a day of the week.
Examples of ‘on’ for days and dates
The wedding is on August 21st. (‘on’ comes before a date)
The store is closed on Sundays. (‘on’ comes before a day of the week)
I usually work on the weekend. (‘on’ comes before days of the week)
Do you have to work on Christmas? (‘on’ comes before a holiday)
## ‘IN’ FOR PLACE & TIME
The preposition ‘in’ is used for broad times and places.
‘In’ for general places
In the conversation, Pailin says:
The food in LA is good but expensive.
‘LA’ is a city, which is a general place, not a specific one like ‘the library.’
‘In’ comes before enclosed spaces, like ‘in the box,’ and also large areas, like neighborhoods, cities, and countries.
Examples of ‘in’ for general places
The keys are in my bag. (‘in’ comes before enclosed spaces)
I’m in the kitchen. (‘in’ comes before enclosed spaces)
My sister lives in Chinatown. (‘in’ comes before a neighborhood)
The Olympics will be in London. (‘in’ comes before a city)
What time is it now in Mexico? (‘in’ comes before a country)
‘In’ for long periods of time
‘In’ comes before longer periods of time, like months, seasons, and years.
Examples of ‘in’ for long periods of time
My birthday is in June. (‘in’ comes before a month)
Chicago is freezing in winter. (‘in’ comes before a season)
He was born in 1995. (‘in’ comes before a year)

lesson.title: What’re you doing tonight?
lesson.focus: How to ask what someone is doing later
lesson.backstory: Pailin has just finished her East Asian Art class, when her phone starts ringing.

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: Hey Pailin! It’s Enzo, from class.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Hey!

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: What’re you doing tonight?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Nothing. Do you have any plans?

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: I have to run some errands right now, but I’ll be free around 6:30. Do you want to get a drink with me?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, that sounds great. Let’s meet at 7 at Jameson's Pub.

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: Okay. I’ll text you when I get there.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Cool. See you later!

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to ask what someone is doing later
## OPEN-ENDED QUESTIONS
In the conversation, Enzo wants to know what Pailin’s plans are for the night:
Enzo: What’re you doing tonight?
Pailin: Nothing.
Present continuous tense for future plans
You learned in Lesson 4.1 that present continuous tense is often used to discuss future plans. This is why Enzo asks ‘What’re you doing tonight?’ rather than asking ‘What will you do tonight?’, which is technically correct but sounds unnatural.
Common questions
Some other ways to ask what someone is doing in the future include:
## TABLE-5:
## TABLE-5:
These are open-ended questions.
No plans
In the conversation, Pailin responds with, ‘Nothing.’ Other similar and common responses are:
Nothing.
No plans.
Nothing planned.
Just hanging out at home.
Busy with plans
If she did have plans, she could respond with:
I’m [verb-ing].
Again, notice that the response uses present continuous tense for discussing future plans or arrangements.
Example responses
I’m working tonight.
I’m visiting my grandparents tomorrow.
I’m going fishing today.
I’m studying for a test this weekend.
YES / NO QUESTIONS
The questions above are open-ended, but you can ask if someone is free later with a yes/no question.
In the conversation, Pailin asks Enzo:
Do you have any plans?
She could have asked ‘Do you have any plans tonight?’ but ‘tonight’ is omitted because it’s mentioned in Enzo’s previous question.
Common questions
Some other ways to find out if someone is available include:
## TABLE-6:
## TABLE-6:
These are yes/no questions.
Example response
Enzo responds to Pailin with:
I have to run some errands right now, but I’ll be free around 6:30.
He could have also responded with a simple:
Nope, I’m free.
‘Are you free?’ vs. ‘Are you busy?’
Notice that the questions ‘Are you free tonight?’ and ‘Are you busy tonight?’ are asking opposite things.
For example, if you are working tomorrow, here’s how to answer:
Pailin: Are you free tomorrow?
Luke: No, I’m not. I’m working tomorrow.
Pailin: Are you busy tomorrow?
Luke: Yeah, I’m working all day.

lesson.title: Can I see your IDs, please?
lesson.focus: How to use the modal verb ‘can’
lesson.backstory: Pailin and her classmate Enzo are about to enter Jameson's Pub, a bar near UCLA.

transcript.speaker: Host
transcript.line_text: Hi guys, can I see your IDs, please?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Sure, here you go.

transcript.speaker: Host
transcript.line_text: Thanks. Would you like to sit inside or outside?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Can we sit outside? It’s a bit loud inside.

transcript.speaker: Host
transcript.line_text: Sure, you can sit at the table over there in the corner. …

transcript.speaker: Server
transcript.line_text: Hi, what can I get for you tonight?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Umm, do you want any appetizers, Enzo?

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: I don’t have my glasses, so I can’t read the menu. But I am a little hungry.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Do you want to share the chips and salsa?

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: I can’t eat the salsa. I’m allergic to tomatoes. But I can snack on the chips.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay! Can we have the chips and salsa and two Heinekens, please? Thank you!

comprehension_questions.prompt: Why does Pailin want to sit outside?

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use the modal verb ‘can’
## CAN
You will use the verb ‘can’ often in English. It has simple grammar and has two main uses:
To show permission
To show ability
Examples from the conversation
These lines from the conversation demonstrate both:
You can sit at the table over there in the corner.
Permission: The host is allowing Pailin and Enzo to sit at that specific table.
I can snack on the chips.
Ability: Enzo is unable to eat the salsa because he’s allergic, but he’s able to eat the chips.
While Thai might use different words to demonstrate permission and ability, English uses ‘can’ for both.
Sentence structure - Affirmative sentences
The best part? The grammar is simple! The structure stays the same no matter what the subject of the sentence is.
[Subject] can [verb]
Examples showing permission
You can borrow my pen.
We can park our car on the street.
You can bring a guest to the party.
Examples showing ability
Chloe can speak three languages.
My dad can sing really well.
I can run a mile in 6 minutes.
## NEGATIVE SENTENCES
The following negative sentences from the conversation demonstrate ability, or rather, lack of ability, by using the word ‘can’t.’
I don’t have my glasses, so I can’t read the menu.
I can’t eat the salsa. I’m allergic to tomatoes.
Enzo is unable to read the menu without his glasses, and he’s unable to eat salsa because he’s allergic to tomatoes.
Sentence structure - Negative sentences
The structure of negative sentences is also simple:
[Subject] can’t [verb]
‘Can’t’ is a contraction of ‘cannot’.
Pronunciation of ‘can’ and ‘can’t’
Because ‘can’ and ‘can't’ sound so similar, they are easy words to misunderstand, even for native English speakers! Don't be afraid to ask someone for clarification if you’re unsure whether they said ‘can’ or ‘can’t.’
While you can say the full word ‘cannot’ if you’re worried about being misunderstood, it’s still much more common to say ‘can’t.’
Examples showing lack of permission
We can’t take photos in the museum.
You can’t park your car here. You’ll get a ticket.
I can’t use my phone at work. My boss will get angry.
Examples showing lack of ability
I can’t speak Spanish.
He can’t hear anything. It’s too noisy.
Emily can’t focus on her work. She’s distracted.
## MAKING QUESTIONS
Take a look at these questions from the conversation that use ‘can’:
Can I see your IDs, please?
Can we sit outside? It’s a bit loud inside.
Can we have the chips and salsa and two Heinekens, please?
These questions all demonstrate permission. The host is requesting permission to see their IDs. Pailin is asking if they’re allowed to sit outside. Pailin is requesting chips and salsa and two beers from the waiter.
‘Can’ in a common phrase
Look at this question from the conversation:
What can I get for you tonight?
This one is a little different. While it hints at ability, it's really an offer of service and is a common phrase used by servers for taking orders.
Sentence structure - Questions
To form questions, simply switch the position of the subject and ‘can.’
Can [subject] [verb] ?
Examples requesting permission
Can I use your phone?
Can we sit here?
Can I try on these shoes?
Examples asking about ability
Can you swim?
Can she speak Korean?
Can you finish the project by Friday?
## ‘CAN’ IS A MODAL VERB
‘Can’ is a type of verb called a modal verb, which you can think of as a ‘helping’ verb. Modal verbs ‘help’ the main verb of a sentence by adding extra meaning or context.
For example:
I can snack on the chips.
Can = modal (helping) verb
Snack = main verb
Without the modal verb ‘can’, the sentence ‘I snack on chips’ would imply a regular activity or routine, as it’s a present simple tense sentence.
‘Can’ alters the meaning of the sentence by suggesting an ability to snack on the chips.
Other modal verbs
The verb ‘will’ is another example of a modal verb, which you learned about in Lesson 3.12. Other common modal verbs include:
could
should
would
might
must
Simple grammar!
The great thing about modal verbs is their grammar is simple, as the modal verb and main verbs don’t change their form based on the subject.

sections.content:
## SHORT FORM ANSWERS
Remember that you can answer yes/no questions with a simple ‘Yes’ or ‘No,’ but short form answers can help maintain the flow of a conversation.
To answer questions beginning with ‘Can’:
- Use the modal verbs ‘can’ or ‘can’t’ in your answers
Examples
Luke: Can you play the guitar?
Pailin: Yeah, I can.
Luke: Can I park here?
Pailin: No, you can’t.
Luke: Can Jack read Japanese?
Pailin: No, he can’t.

sections.content:
## MISTAKE #1
When answering ‘Can’ questions in short form, Thai people often omit the subject of the sentence in their answer.
Incorrect & correct responses
Pailin: Can you wash the dishes?
Luke: Yes, I can. [✓]
Luke: Yes, can. [X]
Pailin: Can you give me a discount, please?
Luke: No, I can’t. [✓]
	Luke: No, cannot. [X]
## MISTAKE #2
Another common mistake is using the phrase ‘Can do’, which doesn’t have a subject, and is therefore an incomplete idea. The correct way to respond is with ‘I can.’
Pailin: Can you help me carry these boxes?
Luke: Yes, I can. [✓]
Luke: Yes, can do. [X]

sections.content:
## LEGAL DRINKING AGE
The legal drinking age in the US is 21 and is strictly enforced. Businesses like grocery stores, restaurants, bars, and clubs will always ask to see an ID to avoid penalties for selling alcohol to minors, even when the customer is clearly over 21.
Although the legal drinking age is 21, the age of legal adulthood is 18. This means that at 18, you can vote, join the military, get married, and move out of your parents’ home, but you can’t buy alcohol or cigarettes until you’re 21.

lesson.title: I want to go dancing!
lesson.focus: How to use 'want' before nouns and verbs
lesson.backstory: Pailin and her classmate Enzo are at Jameson's Pub, a bar near UCLA. They've just finished their first beer, and are deciding what to do next.

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: Do you want to get another beer?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, let’s get another. Actually, I want to drink a cocktail. I’ll get a mojito. Do you want a cocktail, too?

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: Hmm. I want to stick with beer. I’ll be hungover if I drink a cocktail.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay, I’ll go order our drinks at the bar. Which beer do you want?

transcript.speaker: Enzo
transcript.line_text: Oh, thanks! I want a bottle of Asahi. Do you want to go to another bar after this? Or do you want to head home?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I want to go dancing somewhere!

What is the next drink that Enzo will get?
What does Pailin want to do after leaving this bar?
options: A. She wants to head home.
B. She wants to go to another bar.
C. She wants to go dancing.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use 'want' before nouns and verbs
WANT + NOUN
‘Want’ followed by a noun expresses both immediate and general desires.
Take a look at these sentences from the conversation:
Do you want a cocktail?
Which beer do you want?
I want a bottle of Asahi.
Pailin and Enzo are discussing what they’ll order right now, using ‘want’ to show an immediate desire.
English vs. Thai
While Thai speakers might use a word like เอา (‘take’) in this context, English speakers use ‘want’ for both immediate desires (like ordering drinks) and general desires (like ‘I want a new car’).
Examples of ‘want’ for immediate desires
Pete wants a slice of pizza.
I made cookies. Do you want some?
I don’t want this dress. It’s too small. Do you want it?
She wants a cheeseburger with no onions.
Examples of ‘want’ for general desires
Chloe wants a new job.
Pete wants a girlfriend.
What do you want for your birthday?
I don’t want a small apartment.
WANT TO + VERB (AFFIRMATIVE & NEGATIVE SENTENCES)
The verb ‘want’ is also used before verbs to express an immediate or general desire to do something.
Take a look at the following sentences from the conversation. They all express an immediate desire:
Do you want to get another beer?
I want to drink a cocktail.
I want to stick with beer.
Do you want to go to another bar after this?
Do you want to head home?
I want to go dancing somewhere!
Notice the difference
The structure when using ‘want’ before a noun and a verb has one small difference. Can you notice it?
I want a cocktail.
I want to drink a cocktail.
The word ‘to’ must come before the verb.
Affirmative & negative sentence structure
Here is the structure for affirmative and negative sentences using ‘want’ before a verb.

Question structure

## WANT TO VS. WANNA
‘Want to’ is often pronounced as ‘wanna’ in speech.
In the conversation, notice how these sentences are spoken:
I want to drink a cocktail.
I wanna drink a cocktail.
I want to stick with beer.
I wanna stick with beer.
Do you want to go back to the hotel?
Do you wanna go back to the hotel?
I want to go dancing somewhere!
I wanna go dancing somewhere!
‘Wanna’ instead of ‘Do you want to’
When asking ‘Do you want to’ questions, you can further shorten the question so it starts with ‘Wanna.’
For example, these questions from the conversation could be asked as:
Do you want to get another beer?
Wanna get another beer?
Do you want to go to another bar after this?
Wanna go to another bar after this?

sections.content:
## LEISURE ACTIVITIES
Notice in the conversation, Pailin doesn’t say ‘I want to dance.’ Instead, she says:
I want to go dancing.
Sentence structure
For many leisure activities, the following structure is commonly used:
want to go [verb-ing]
Common leisure activities
go swimming
go shopping
go running
go hiking
go dancing
go camping
go fishing
go surfing
Examples
I want to go shopping in Paris.
Do you want to go camping next weekend?
He doesn’t want to go fishing today.
Either structure is fine!
It’s perfectly fine to use ‘I want to [verb]’ in these instances, like ‘I want to hike’ or ‘I want to shop.’
It’s just more common to use the ‘go [verb-ing]’ structure, like ‘I want to go hiking’ or ‘I want to go shopping.’
Verbs that require objects
Note that ‘go [verb-ing]’ isn’t used for verbs that require an object, like the verb ‘play,’ which usually comes before a noun.
For example, ‘I want to go playing tennis’ is incorrect to say, even though tennis can be a leisure activity. In this case, you should stick with ‘I want to play tennis.’
SHORT FORM ANSWERS - WANT + NOUN
To answer questions that use ‘want [noun]’, such as ‘Do you want a piece of chocolate?’, your short form answer should:
- Use ‘do · does’ for ‘yes’ answers
- Use ‘don’t · doesn’t’ for ‘no’ answers
Examples
Pailin: Do they want kids?
Luke: Yeah, they do.
Pailin: Does he want a new phone?
Luke: No, he doesn’t.
SHORT FORM ANSWERS - WANT TO + VERB
There are two short form ways to answer questions that use ‘want to [verb].’
You can use auxiliary verbs like ‘do’ or ‘doesn’t’ in your answer
You can use ‘want to’ or ‘don’t want to’ in your answer
*Note: You can’t answer with just ‘want’ - you must say ‘want to’
Examples
Pailin: Do you want to drive?
Luke: Yeah, I do.
Luke: Yeah, I want to.
Pailin: Does Chloe want to come to the party?
Luke: Yeah, she does.
Luke: Yeah, she wants to.
Pailin: Do they want to try a new restaurant?
Luke: No, they don’t.
Luke: No, they don’t want to.
Pailin: Does your son want to go to college?
Luke: No, he doesn’t.
Luke: No, he doesn’t want to.

sections.content:
## MISTAKE #1
Thai people often use the following incorrect verb structure:
want to [verb-ing]
Remember to always follow this verb structure:
want to [verb]
Incorrect & correct sentences
They want to going to the mall. [X]
They want to go to the mall. [✓]
I want to watching the next episode. [X]
I want to watch the next episode. [✓]
## MISTAKE #2
Thai people often answer these yes/no questions in the following incorrect way:
Luke: Do you want to sleep soon?
Pailin: Yes, I want. [X]
Luke: Do they want to watch a movie?
Pailin: No, they not want. [X]
Luke: Does he want to do yoga?
Pailin: No, he don’t want. [X]
Remember, your short form answer can follow two different structures, as outlined in the Extra Tips section.
Correct responses
Luke: Do you want to sleep soon?
Pailin: Yes, I do. [✓]
Pailin: Yes, I want to. [✓]
Luke: Do they want to watch a movie?
Pailin: No, they don’t. [✓]
Pailin: No, they don’t want to. [✓]
Luke: Does he want to do yoga?
Pailin: No, he doesn’t. [✓]
Pailin: No, he doesn’t want to. [✓]

lesson.focus: How to say that something hurts
lesson.backstory: It's morning, and Pailin is walking into the kitchen where she sees her host brother Luke. She had a night of drinking and dancing the night before with her classmate Enzo.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Morning, Pailin.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Morning.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Do you have a cold? You sound sick.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I’m so hungover. I have a headache and a stomach ache.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Here, I have aspirin. You can have one.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Thanks. You were out last night too, right?

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Yep. I feel okay. I don’t have a hangover. I’m just tired, and my shoulder hurts.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Oh, you have a huge bruise on your shoulder. How did that happen?

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Oh yeah, some guy bumped into me at the bar.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Ouch, it looks like it hurts. Man, I’m never drinking alcohol again.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to say that something hurts
## ACHES
Pailin isn’t doing too well this morning after her night out with Enzo. She sounds pretty rough. She tells her host brother Luke:
I have a headache and a stomach ache.
[Body part]-ache
When a specific part of your body aches, you can say:
I have a [body part]-ache.
When a body part and -ache are combined, they form a noun. This is why the sentence becomes ‘I HAVE a bodyache.’ Common examples of these body aches are:
I have a headache.
I have a stomach ache.
I have a backache.
I have a toothache.
I have an earache.
Note that this sentence structure is used almost exclusively with the body aches listed above.
[Body part] hurts
When other parts of the body are in pain, you should say:
My [body part] hurts.
For example, in the conversation, Luke didn’t say ‘I have a shoulder ache.’ He says:
My shoulder hurts.
This sentence structure is useful in that it can describe a pain in any part of the body.
Examples
My wrist hurts.
My whole body hurts from the gym yesterday.
My knee hurts after that hike.
My eyes hurt from staring at the computer all day.
## INJURIES & AILMENTS
In the conversation, Pailin tells Luke:
You have a big bruise on your shoulder.
Injuries
When you have an injury, you can use the same sentence structure for when you have a body ache:
I have [an injury].
Important injuries to know
a cut
a bruise
a sunburn
a broken [body part]
Ailments
This following sentence structure also applies to ailments:
I have [an ailment].
Important ailments to know
a sore throat
a fever
a cold
a cough
a runny nose
a stuffy nose
allergies
a rash
a hangover
cramps
diarrhea
## USEFUL PHRASE
I’m sick.
No one likes to say it, but it happens to all of us. 😥

sections.content:
## HANGOVER VS. HUNGOVER
Compare these two lines from the conversation:
Pailin: I’m so hungover.
Luke: I don’t have a hangover.
‘Hungover’ = adjective
‘Hangover’ = noun
This difference in parts of speech dictates how these words are used in sentences.
‘Hungover’ is a feeling, so it fits in the pattern ‘I’m so [adjective].’
‘Hangover’ is a noun, so it’s a condition you have, which is why Luke says ‘I don’t have a hangover’ rather than ‘I’m not hangover.’
## SORE MUSCLES
To describe muscle pain after exercise, use the word ‘sore’ with this sentence structure:
[Body part] is sore.
Examples
My calves are sore after the run.
My back is sore from sitting all day.
My thighs are so sore after yesterday’s workout.

## MISTAKE #1
Thai people often mispronounce the word ‘ache’ like ‘ay-ch’ or the letter ‘H.’ Although it has a ‘ch’ in it, the word is pronounced like ‘ake’.
Headache
Stomach ache
## MISTAKE #2
Thai people often use the following structure, which is incorrect:
I’m [body part]-ache. [X]
I’m headache. [X]
Remember that an ‘ache’ is a noun, so the sentence structure must be:
I have a [body part]-ache. [✓]
I have a headache. [✓]
## MISTAKE #3
Similar to the mistake mentioned above, Thai people often mix up the use of ‘hangover’ and ‘hungover’ in a sentence. The following sentence is incorrect:
I’m hangover. [X]
Remember that a ‘hangover’ is a noun, so the sentence must be:
I have a hangover. [✓]
An easy trick to remember this is ‘have’ and ‘hangover’ both begin with ‘ha-’.
Since ‘hungover’ is an adjective, that is the correct word to use in this sentence:
I’m hungover. [✓]

lesson.title: I had a really bad day
lesson.focus:
How to use common irregular past tense verbs
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #1)
lesson.backstory: Pailin has just arrived home after a day of classes at UCLA. She starts chatting with her host mom Sylvie.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I had a really bad day.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Oh no! What happened?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: First, I saw a car accident. The police came, and I had to tell them what I saw.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Oh no! Was everyone okay?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I’m not sure, but I hope so. Then, I was late to class, and my professor was not happy.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: That sounds stressful.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: It gets worse! After class, a guy ran into me, and I spilled my coffee everywhere. It got on his jacket, and he got mad at me!

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: What? But it wasn’t your fault!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I know! But he was so rude.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Well, maybe some hot chocolate will cheer you up. I just made some!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Wow, thank you! I would really love some.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
Introduction to common past tense verbs
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #1)
## INTRODUCTION TO PAST SIMPLE TENSE
Past simple tense is the verb tense used to describe actions or events that happened in the past and are now finished.
It’s a fundamental tense in English, and because it’s used so often, this tense has been divided into 3 lessons.
In this lesson, the idea is to grasp the use of past simple tense and to introduce you to common past tense verbs.
The conversation
In the conversation, Pailin tells Sylvie about a series of unfortunate events that happened during her day. Pailin’s bad day is over, and she’s finally home. When she tells Sylvie about her bad day, she uses past simple tense, because these events happened in the past.
## ‘WAS’ AND ‘WERE’
You learned about the past tense to-be verbs ‘was’ and ‘were’ in Lesson 2.8, which are the most used past tense verbs in English.
‘Was’ is used several times in this conversation:
I was late to class.
My professor was not happy.
It wasn’t your fault!
He was so rude.
Present vs. past tense to-be verbs
The present tense to-be verb ‘is’ can’t be used in these sentences because Pailin isn’t describing something that is currently happening, but rather something that already happened before this conversation.
## QUICK PRACTICE
## ITEM: 1
## ITEM: 2
## ITEM: 3
## COMMON PAST TENSE VERBS
Take a look at these lines from the conversation:
I had a really bad day.
I saw a car accident.
The police came.
I had to tell them what I saw.
A guy ran into me.
He got mad at me.
The underlined words are all past tense verbs, and they are some of the most used past tense verbs in English.
Present & past tense verb forms
## TABLE-9:
## TABLE-9:
Practice makes perfect!
You might be wondering, what’s the pattern to change the present tense verb into its past tense form?
The sad news is that these verbs, which are called ‘irregular past tense verbs,’ don’t follow a pattern - they are ‘irregular.’ You simply have to memorize them.
Luckily, many of them are very common, and you'll remember them quickly because you'll use them often.
More examples
Here are more examples using the past tense verbs above, with past tense time markers:
I had a meeting this morning with my boss.
We saw a shooting star last night!
He came home late yesterday.
Pailin ran a marathon last year.
She got a new job last month.
No verb changes
There is some good news with past simple tense - there is no change to the verb when different subjects are used, with the exception of ‘was’ and ‘were.’
Common past tense verbs
Here are a few more common irregular past tense verbs with example sentences:
## TABLE-10:
## TABLE-10:
The only way to get familiar with irregular past tense verbs is to practice using them! Try making sentences with the past tense verbs discussed in this lesson.
## QUICK PRACTICE
## ITEM: 1
## ITEM: 2
## ITEM: 3
## COMPARING VERB TENSES
Compare the verb tenses you’ve learned so far using the verb ‘go’:
Present simple tense:
Used for habits, routines, and present feelings.
I go to the gym every morning.
My family goes to France every summer.
Future simple tense:
Used for things that will happen in the future.
I’ll go to the post office after work.
We’ll go hiking tomorrow morning.
Present continuous tense:
Used for things happening right now, and for arranged plans in the future.
I’m going to the park right now.
They’re going to Bangkok next week.
Past simple tense:
Used for actions and events that happened in the past.
I went to the beach last weekend.
My parents went to the post office already.
In Lesson 4.15 and Lesson 4.16, you will learn about more past tense verbs, along with forming negative sentences and questions in past simple tense.

lesson.title: One moment, please!
lesson.focus: How to tell someone to wait
lesson.backstory: Pailin is at the student bookstore at UCLA, where she is looking for a book. Her friend Chloe will meet her at the bookstore before they head to their next class together.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Excuse me, can you help me find a book?

transcript.speaker: Cashier
transcript.line_text: Of course! Just a moment, please...Okay, how can I help you?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I'm looking for a book called The History of Jazz.

transcript.speaker: Cashier
transcript.line_text: Okay, one moment, let me check the computer...Oh, I'm so sorry, but it's sold out.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Oh, darn. How about The History of Rock. Do you have that?

transcript.speaker: Cashier
transcript.line_text: Yes, we have it! You can follow me...Here it is.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Great, thank you so much.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: *enters the store* Hey Pai, did you find your book?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yep! Give me a sec while I check out.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: No problem. I'll be right back, I need to go to the bathroom. Let's meet at the entrance.

comprehension_questions.prompt: Which book will Pailin buy from the bookstore?
Where will Pailin meet Chloe after buying her book?

items.text: You just made some salad for you and your friend. He’s about to take a bite when you remember you didn’t put any dressing on it. What can you say?
options: A. Hang on, I forgot to put dressing on the salad.
B. Wait a moment, I forgot to put dressing on the salad.

items.text: You’re a server at a busy restaurant. As you’re bringing plates of food to a table, you notice a couple walk through the entrance. What can you say to them?
options: A. Hi, wait a second. I’ll seat you shortly.
B. Hi, I’ll be right with you. I’ll seat you shortly.

items.text: Your spouse is asking if you've checked in online yet for your flight tomorrow. What can you say?
options: A. Give me a sec, I’ll do it right now.
B. One moment please, I’ll do it right now.

items.text: Your colleague approaches you to chat, but you’re in the middle of a phone call. What could you say to your colleague to ask them to wait while you wrap up your phone call?
You’re leaving a restaurant with a friend when you realize you left your phone in the restaurant. What could you say to your friend before you run in to grab your phone?

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to tell someone to wait
## FORMAL PHRASES
There are several phrases used to ask someone to wait, ranging from formal and professional to casual or slang phrases.
Phrases from the conversation
In the conversation, Pailin is talking with a cashier at a bookstore, so he uses polite phrases to ask her to wait:
Just a moment, please.
One moment
‘Moment’ and ‘please’
The word ‘moment’ is slightly more formal than the words ‘minute’ or ‘second,’ which are used in casual phrases.
Adding ‘please’ makes the request more polite.
More formal phrases
Please wait a moment.
Can you give me a moment, please?
I’ll be right with you.
This would be used by service professionals like store clerks, servers, or receptionists. It’s used to acknowledge a customer and let them know they’ll be helped once they’re free.
## CASUAL PHRASES
Later in the conversation, Chloe enters the bookstore. Since Chloe and Pailin are friends, Pailin uses a casual phrase to ask Chloe to wait for her:
Give me a sec
‘Sec’ is an abbreviation of ‘second,’ so Pailin could also say:
Give me a second
This phrase is a literal request for the other person to give them a short time to finish their task.
More casual, polite phrases
Just a second (or ‘sec’)
Just a minute
These are used when you’re preoccupied with something and need a moment to finish your task. For example, if you’re on the phone with someone, and your friend enters the room to talk to you, you can tell your friend, ‘Just a sec’ as you finish up your phone call.
Wait a second (or ‘sec’)
Wait a minute
These can be used when you need to physically stop what you’re doing (‘Wait a sec, I need to grab my keys’) or when you’re trying to remember information (‘Wait a second, I’m trying to remember his name’).
‘Minute’ and ‘second’
‘Minute’ and ‘second’ are pretty much interchangeable, although ‘minute’ can suggest a slightly longer pause than ‘second.’ The above phrases are casual but also polite.
Informal phrases
The following phrases are quite informal and should only be used with friends and family:
Wait
Hang on · Hold on
These are interchangeable, and both are used often.
Hold up
This is a newer slang phrase.
Try to avoid saying these to strangers or in a work environment, and opt for a more polite phrase instead.
## USEFUL PHRASE
In the conversation, Chloe heads to the bathroom and tells Pailin:
I’ll be right back.
You can use this handy phrase when you plan to return very quickly. It can be used in any situation with anyone, like friends and colleagues. It’s even used by store employees when talking with customers.

lesson.title: So many things at the yard sale
lesson.backstory: Pailin and Chloe have a break between their classes, so they decide to check out a yard sale near UCLA.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Wow, there are so many things here! Look at this jacket.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: It's so nice! And there are so many books too. Do you need any books?

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: No, I already have too many books. But I don’t have much furniture in my room. I want to find a small table.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: There's probably a small table here. Oh, they have so much jewelry here! I don't wear much jewelry, but my mom does. She'll love this necklace.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: How much is it?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Let me check...It's only five dollars!

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: That's so cheap. Get it!

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to use ‘many’ and ‘much’
## MANY VS. MUCH
The words ‘much’ and ‘many’ are used to talk about quantity. However, they’re used with different types of nouns:
Many
- Used with countable nouns, which are things you can count individually
- Countable noun examples: books, women, cats, flowers, ideas
Much
- Used with uncountable nouns, which are things you can’t count individually
- Uncountable noun examples: water, sugar, plastic, rice, money, art, homework
## MANY
These lines from the conversation use the word ‘many’:
There are so many things here!
There are so many books too.
I already have too many books.
The words ‘books’ and ‘things’ are countable nouns, meaning you could say ‘I have three books’ or ‘There are three things on my desk.’ So, the word ‘many’ must be used with them.
Modifiers before ‘many’
‘Many’ by itself means a large quantity. However, the word ‘many’ often comes after a modifier word that adds more specific information about the quantity.
For example:
There are so many books too.
‘So many’ means there is a very large quantity of books.
I already have too many books.
‘Too many’ means Chloe has an excessive amount of books.
I don’t have many books at home.
‘Not many’ means you have just a small quantity of books.
How many books do you have?
This question asks about the quantity of books.
Many + plural nouns
Note that the countable noun must be plural when used with ‘many,’ as you can see in the example sentences above.
## MUCH
These lines from the conversation use ‘much’:
I don’t have much furniture in my room.
They have so much jewelry here!
I don’t wear much jewelry.
How much is it?
The words ‘furniture’ and ‘jewelry’ are uncountable nouns. So, you can’t say ‘I bought three furniture’ but must say ‘I bought three pieces of furniture’ instead. The word ‘much’ is used with these uncountable nouns.
Modifiers before ‘much’
‘Much’ by itself means a large quantity, but just as with the word ‘many,’ it often comes with a modifier word that adds information about the degree or extent of ‘much.’
For example:
I don’t have much furniture in my room.
‘Not much’ means Chloe has a small quantity of furniture.
They have so much jewelry here!
‘So much’ means there is a very large quantity of jewelry.
I don’t wear much jewelry.
This means that Pailin rarely wears jewelry.
How much is it?
This question asks about the cost or price of the necklace. ‘Cost’ is an uncountable noun.
## MORE EXAMPLES
Here are more example sentences of ‘many’ with countable nouns:
I saw so many car accidents on the freeway.
You packed too many shirts for this trip.
There aren’t many people in the library.
How many lemons did you buy?
Here are more example sentences of ‘much’ with uncountable nouns:
There’s so much stuff in my bag!
This soup has too much salt.
I don’t have much cash in my wallet.
How much time do we have before the movie starts?

sections.content:
## ‘SO MUCH’ WITH VERBS
The phrase ‘so much’ can also modify a verb to show a strong feeling or a large amount of the action.
‘So much’ should come after the verb or at the end of the sentence.
Examples
I like him so much!
Thank you so much!
I miss you so much.
He cares so much about his family.
I hate cleaning so much.
She respects you so much.
I regret saying that so much.

sections.content:
## YARD SALES
'Yard sales' or 'garage sales' are a common and casual way for people to sell their unwanted things. They will put all their used items in the front yard to invite people walking by to browse their goods. Yard sales are usually held on weekends, and sellers will often post signs around the neighborhood to advertise the yard sale's time and location.
Yard sales are a cool way for you to find interesting furniture, clothes, and household goods at super low prices, as the seller often just wants to get rid of things quickly to declutter their home. Yard sales are more common in the suburbs, where most homes have spacious yards, but sometimes you can find them in the city.
If you see signs for a yard sale while in the US, take the opportunity to check them out! You never know what unique things you'll find.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to ask someone to repeat themselves
## POLITE PHRASES
There are several ways to ask someone to repeat themselves if you didn’t hear them clearly.
Polite and proper phrase
In the conversation, the cashier speaks very quickly, and Pailin doesn’t understand what he is saying. So, she requests:
Sorry, could you say that one more time, please?
This is a very polite way to ask an employee or a stranger to repeat themselves.
Shorter alternative
An alternative is:
Could you say that again, please?
More casual alternative
The second time Pailin can’t understand the cashier, she says to him:
What was that?
This is another polite phrase that can be used with anyone - friends, colleagues, and strangers. It’s much more polite than simply asking ‘What?’
Even shorter alternative!
Sometimes it’s shortened to:
What’s that?
Sorry
Adding ‘Sorry’ to the beginning of all these phrases can make them even more polite.
Super simple phrases
Perhaps the easiest phrases to say to someone if you didn’t hear them are:
Excuse me?
Sorry?
Make sure to say these two phrases with a polite, questioning tone, rather than a flat or abrupt tone, or else they can sound aggressive and confrontational.
## CASUAL PHRASES
The following phrases are very casual ways to ask someone to repeat themselves:
What did you say?
What?
While they’re common in relaxed settings with friends and family, they can sound abrupt or even rude if said to strangers or used in professional settings. Phrases from the previous section are more suitable when speaking with strangers or employees.
## COULD YOU SPEAK MORE SLOWLY?
Sometimes, you might speak with a person who naturally talks very fast.
Instead of asking them to constantly repeat themselves, you can politely ask them to try speaking more slowly with:
Could you speak more slowly, please?

inlines.text: ‘Pardon?’ is another polite way of asking someone to repeat themselves, but it’s used much more widely in British English. It’s not used often in American English, but it’s still understood.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.13: That’ll be $3, please

inlines.text: Americans are more likely to use alternatives like ‘Excuse me?’ or ‘What was that?’ or any of the phrases listed in the Understand section.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.13: That’ll be $3, please

sections.content:
## PARDON?
‘Pardon?’ is another polite way of asking someone to repeat themselves, but it’s used much more widely in British English. It’s not used often in American English, but it’s still understood.
Americans are more likely to use alternatives like ‘Excuse me?’ or ‘What was that?’ or any of the phrases listed in the Understand section.

inlines.text: While cash is still common in Thailand, QR code payments have rapidly become the leading method for everyday transactions.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.13: That’ll be $3, please

inlines.text: This streamlined approach is quite different from the US, where many different payment methods are all widely used. It’s typical for one person to use debit cards, credit cards, cash, and digital wallets like Apple Pay, Venmo, and Zelle.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.13: That’ll be $3, please

sections.content:
## PAYMENT SYSTEMS IN THE US
While cash is still common in Thailand, QR code payments have rapidly become the leading method for everyday transactions.
This streamlined approach is quite different from the US, where many different payment methods are all widely used. It’s typical for one person to use debit cards, credit cards, cash, and digital wallets like Apple Pay, Venmo, and Zelle.

lesson.title: What’s in guacamole?
lesson.focus: How to ask what something is called
lesson.backstory: Pailin is ordering food at Chipotle, a fast-casual Mexican restaurant known for their burritos, tacos, and bowls.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Hi, I’ll have one beef burrito, please.

transcript.speaker: Worker
transcript.line_text: Okay, with a side of chips or a side of French fries?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I’ll take the side of chips. What’s this green stuff called?

transcript.speaker: Worker
transcript.line_text: It’s called ‘guacamole.’

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: What’s in it?

transcript.speaker: Worker
transcript.line_text: It’s mostly avocado, onion, and cilantro. Here, you can try some.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Thanks…mmm, it’s so good!

transcript.speaker: Worker
transcript.line_text: It goes great with chips.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay, I’ll take some…what’s it called again? Guala…?

transcript.speaker: Worker
transcript.line_text: Guacamole.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, one side of that, please.

## LESSON FOCUS
How to ask what something is called
## WHAT’S THIS CALLED?
In the conversation, Pailin sees a dip that she’s unfamiliar with. She asks the worker:
What’s this green stuff called?
If she was pointing at it, she could also simply ask:
What’s this called?
When you travel or move abroad, you’ll surely encounter foods and items that you’ve never seen before. This is a useful question to ask in those moments.
How to respond
The worker responds with:
It’s called ‘guacamole.’
You can follow this structure to say the name of something:
It’s called ‘[the name of the item].’
It’s called ‘durian.’
It’s called a ‘thermometer.’
What’s this called in English?
If you want to know what something is called in another language, you can ask:
What’s this called in [language]?
What’s this called in English?
What’s this called in Spanish?
How do you say this in English?
If you want to know how a specific word or phrase is said in another language, you can ask:
How do you say [a word or phrase] in [language]?
How do you say ‘pineapple’ in Spanish?
How do you say ‘I love you’ in Thai?

sections.content:
## US VS. UK ENGLISH
While the USA and the UK share English as a common language, there are some notable differences in their vocabulary.
Chips, fries, and crisps
One example is the word ‘chips.’ In the US, chips are a crunchy snack, like Lays or Pringles, while these are called ‘crisps’ in the UK. On the other hand, what Americans call 'French fries' are called 'chips' in the UK.
Cookies and biscuits
Another example is the word ‘biscuits.’ In the UK, biscuits are what Americans call ‘cookies,’ whereas in the US, biscuits are a buttery, flaky bread, similar to a scone. Here are some other vocabulary differences between the two countries:
