lesson.title: I visited LA last year
lesson.focus:
How to make regular past tense verbs with -ed
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #2)
lesson.backstory: It's evening, and Pailin is at home chatting with her host brother Luke.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: So, why did you decide to study in LA?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I wanted to study in a big city, and I also wanted to be near the beach, so I chose LA.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Is this your first time in the States?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: No, I visited LA last year for my sister’s wedding. Her husband is American.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Oh, so does your sister live in LA, too?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: No, she lived here for two years, but she moved to New York City with her husband after they got married.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Cool, I love New York City. I went there a few years ago, and it snowed so much. Even the subway stopped running.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Wow that's crazy. It just rained a lot when I visited New York, but it didn't snow.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Really? It snowed a tiny bit in LA a few years ago!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I didn't know it snows in LA!

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: I mean, it almost never snows. That was just a crazy winter.

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
How to make regular past tense verbs with -ed
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #2)
## REGULAR PAST TENSE VERBS
Lesson 4.10 introduced the past simple verb tense, which is used to describe actions or events that already happened. You learned some common irregular past tense verbs, like ‘saw,’ ‘had,’ and ‘got,’ which have unique or ‘irregular’ past tense forms.
Past tense verbs with -ed
This lesson focuses on regular past tense verbs, which follow a pattern:
[verb] + ed
Examples from the conversation
These lines from the conversation all have regular past tense verbs:
I wanted to study in a big city.
I visited LA last year for my sister’s wedding.
She lived here for two years.
She moved to New York City with her husband.
It snowed so much.
Even the subway stopped running.
It just rained a lot when I visited New York.
Present & past tense verb forms
The chart below shows the present tense and past tense verb forms for these regular verbs:
## TABLE-12:
## TABLE-12:
Pronunciation
To pronounce regular past tense verbs, you usually just add a -d sound to the end of the verb.
But for verbs that end in -t or -d sounds (like ‘want’ or ‘need’), the -ed ending should be fully pronounced as an extra syllable, as in the words ‘wanted’ and ‘needed.’
## COMMON REGULAR PAST TENSE VERBS
Here are more regular past tense verbs you will use often, with example sentences:
## TABLE-13:
## TABLE-13:
## QUICK PRACTICE
## ITEM: 1
## ITEM: 2
## ITEM: 3
## NEGATIVE SENTENCES
Compare these past simple tense sentences from the conversation:
It snowed so much. (affirmative)
It didn’t snow. (negative)
The main verb is ‘snow.’ In the affirmative sentence, -ed is added to the verb to make it past tense.
Didn’t
What do you notice in the negative sentence? ‘Didn’t’ comes before the main verb ‘snow.’
‘Didn’t’ is a contraction of ‘did not,’ and is the auxiliary verb used to make ALL past tense sentences negative, regardless of whether the main verb is an irregular or regular verb.
Main verb stays in its base form
Notice that the main verb doesn’t change in the negative sentence, but stays in its base form, so the sentence isn’t ‘It didn’t snowed,’ but rather ‘It didn’t snow.’
Irregular verbs - Negative sentences
Here is an example of past simple tense sentences using the irregular verb ‘take’:
She took the subway to work. (affirmative)
She didn’t take the subway to work. (negative)
Here is another example using the irregular verb ‘know’ from the conversation:
I knew it snows in LA. (affirmative)
I didn’t know it snows in LA. (negative)
Negative sentence structure
So, negative sentences using past simple tense follow this pattern:
[subject] didn’t [verb]
Compare the structure to negative sentences in present simple tense:
[subject] don’t [verb]
[subject] doesn’t [verb]
You learned in Lesson 4.10 that ‘did’ is the past verb of ‘do’ and ‘does.’ That’s why ‘didn’t’ is used in past simple negative sentences.
‘Do’ as the main verb
Sometimes, ‘do’ is the main verb of a sentence, so a negative past tense sentence could be:
I didn’t do my homework yesterday.
Examples
He didn’t get the job.
I didn’t say anything.
We didn’t have any problems.
They didn’t cook dinner last night.
Pailin didn’t go to class yesterday.
## QUICK PRACTICE
## MAKING QUESTIONS
‘Did’ is the question word that makes past simple tense sentences into questions.
Pailin could have asked Luke this question in the conversation:
Did it snow in New York City?
The affirmative sentence is ‘It snowed in New York City.’
To make it into a question, ‘Did’ is the question word added to the beginning of the sentence, and ‘snowed’ changes back to the base verb ‘snow.’
Question structure
All questions in past simple tense follow this structure, regardless of whether the verb is regular or irregular:
Did [subject] [verb]?
Compare the structure to questions using present simple tense:
Do [subject] [verb]?
Does [subject] [verb]?
The only change is that the question words ‘do’ and ‘does’ become ‘did’ to indicate past tense.
Examples
Did he get the job?
Did you say something?
Did they have any problems?
Did you cook dinner last night?
Did Pailin go to class yesterday?
## QUICK PRACTICE
## IRREGULAR SPELLING RULES
You can simply add -ed to most of these regular past tense verbs. But there are a few other spelling changes to remember:
Verbs ending in a silent -e:
Just add -d
like → liked
bake → baked
Verbs ending in 1 consonant (letters that aren’t vowels) + -y:
Change the -y to -i before adding -ed
study → studied
try → tried
marry → married
Verbs ending in 1 vowel + 1 consonant (letters that aren’t vowels):
Double the final consonant before adding -ed
stop → stopped
plan → planned
grab → grabbed

## SHORT FORM ANSWERS
To answer past simple tense questions in short form, use the auxiliary verb ‘did’ or ‘didn’t’ in your answers.
For example:
Pailin: Did you wake up early today?
Luke: Yeah, I did.
Pailin: Did he lock the door?
Luke: Yeah, he did.
Pailin: Did she drive to school?
Luke: No, she didn’t.
Pailin: Did they book their flight?
Luke: No, they didn’t.

inlines.text: LOS ANGELES: SUN, SURF, AND SNOW

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: Los Angeles is a famous city to visit and move to largely because of its sunny and warm climate. It pretty much never snows in the city, and while it does rain occasionally, it rarely reaches the level of rain that Thailand gets on a yearly basis.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: Summers in LA can be pretty hot (up to 37°C), but it’s a dry heat, which many people think is more tolerable than a humid heat. Winters in LA can get a little cold (down to 4°C), but nowhere near as cold as most other states.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: LA’s mild climate is thanks to its unique geography - a city bordered by the ocean, mountains, and the desert. Many residents lead active lifestyles, and outdoor sports are especially popular. Here are some unique challenges - are they on your bucket list?

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: Skiing and surfing in the same day. The mountains are a two-hour drive from the city, so you could ski in the morning and surf in the afternoon.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: Skiing, surfing, and skateboarding (or golfing) in the same day.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: In the conversation, Luke refers to the USA as 'the States.' There are 3 ways you can refer to the US:

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: 'USA' stands for the United States of America, and is often shortened to just the 'US.’ 'The States' is a casual way to refer to the country, as the US is made up of 50 states. 'America' is also a casual way to refer to the country.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: The first two are perfectly fine to use, but 'America' can be controversial to some. This is because geographically, 'the Americas' refers to all of North America, Central America, and South America.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: So when Americans use the term 'America' to refer to the USA, it can be seen as nationalistic or self-centered, as it can imply that the US is the default or most important 'America.'

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: For example, technically, a Brazilian is South American, so in a broader sense, they can be 'American' too.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year
LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

inlines.text: However, the use of 'America' to refer to the country is still very common around the world, especially since people from the US are called 'Americans.' To be politically correct, it's best to call the country 'the US' or 'the States,' although 'America' is still widely accepted.

content_jsonb.lesson_context: LESSON 4.15: I visited LA last year

sections.content:
## LOS ANGELES: SUN, SURF, AND SNOW
Los Angeles is a famous city to visit and move to largely because of its sunny and warm climate. It pretty much never snows in the city, and while it does rain occasionally, it rarely reaches the level of rain that Thailand gets on a yearly basis.
Mild climate
Summers in LA can be pretty hot (up to 37°C), but it’s a dry heat, which many people think is more tolerable than a humid heat. Winters in LA can get a little cold (down to 4°C), but nowhere near as cold as most other states.
Beach, mountains, and desert
LA’s mild climate is thanks to its unique geography - a city bordered by the ocean, mountains, and the desert. Many residents lead active lifestyles, and outdoor sports are especially popular. Here are some unique challenges - are they on your bucket list?
California Double:
Skiing and surfing in the same day. The mountains are a two-hour drive from the city, so you could ski in the morning and surf in the afternoon.
California Trifecta:
Skiing, surfing, and skateboarding (or golfing) in the same day.
## 3 NAMES FOR THE USA
In the conversation, Luke refers to the USA as 'the States.' There are 3 ways you can refer to the US:
1. the US / the USA
2. the States
3. America
'USA' stands for the United States of America, and is often shortened to just the 'US.’ 'The States' is a casual way to refer to the country, as the US is made up of 50 states. 'America' is also a casual way to refer to the country.
Politically correct name
The first two are perfectly fine to use, but 'America' can be controversial to some. This is because geographically, 'the Americas' refers to all of North America, Central America, and South America.
So when Americans use the term 'America' to refer to the USA, it can be seen as nationalistic or self-centered, as it can imply that the US is the default or most important 'America.'
For example, technically, a Brazilian is South American, so in a broader sense, they can be 'American' too.
Using ‘America’
However, the use of 'America' to refer to the country is still very common around the world, especially since people from the US are called 'Americans.' To be politically correct, it's best to call the country 'the US' or 'the States,' although 'America' is still widely accepted.

lesson.title: We went to the Santa Monica Pier
lesson.focus:
How to use past tense verbs
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #3)
lesson.backstory: Pailin is at home chatting with her host sister Emily, who is 13 years old. Pailin is telling Emily about her weekend with Chloe at the Santa Monica Pier.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Hey, Pailin! How was your weekend?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: It was great! I went to Santa Monica with Chloe.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Oh, cool! What did you do there?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: We walked on the pier and watched the sunset. It was so pretty!

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Nice! Did you ride the Ferris wheel?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: No, we didn’t. The line was too long. But we played some games at the arcade, and I won a teddy bear!

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Lucky, I never win anything! Did you try the food at Bubba Gump?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah, we ate the shrimp mac and cheese, but I didn't really like it. It was so salty.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Oh, really? I haven't tried it. I love the jambalaya. Can I join you next time you visit the pier?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Sure!

sections.content:
## LESSON FOCUS
A summary of past simple tense
Verb tense: Past simple tense (Lesson #3)
## PAST SIMPLE TENSE STRUCTURE
You’ve now learned about making sentences using past tense verbs:
Affirmative sentences - Past simple tense
Regular past tense verbs:
Add -ed to the verb
Examples: watched, danced, organized, closed
They packed their suitcases yesterday. (base verb: pack)
We unlocked the door this morning. (base verb: unlock)
Irregular past tense verbs:
Have a unique past tense verb form that doesn’t follow any pattern
Examples: saw, had, was, went, made
She drew a nice picture yesterday. (base verb: draw)
I understood Spanish when I was younger. (base verb: understand)
Negative sentences - Past simple tense
You’ve learned about making negative sentences with past simple tense:
[subject] didn’t [verb]
We didn’t go to the mall yesterday.
I didn’t pass the test.
She didn’t drive to work.
Questions - Past simple tense
And you’ve learned about making questions with past simple tense:
Did [subject] [verb]?
Did you sleep okay last night?
Did Sylvie bring her passport?
Did they like the movie?
## REGULAR VS. IRREGULAR PAST TENSE VERBS
You’ve learned about a handful of irregular and regular past tense verbs that are often used. Although most verbs are regular, and become past tense by simply adding -ed, there are also many irregular past tense verbs - around 200.
Focus on common irregular verbs
Rather than memorizing all 200 irregular verbs, it’s best to focus on mastering the common ones through repeated practice.
Relisten to the conversation
Go through the conversation and take note of the irregular and regular past tense verbs that are used. Try also noticing the negative sentences and questions that use past simple tense.
More common irregular verbs
Here is a list of more irregular past tense verbs - again, you’ll notice that there is no pattern that applies to their formation.
## TABLE-14:
## TABLE-14:
Present & past tense verbs that don’t change at all
Some irregular past tense verbs don’t even change at all when switching from present to past tense! For example:
## TABLE-15:
## TABLE-15:
## USES OF PAST SIMPLE TENSE
As mentioned before, past simple tense is used for actions or events that happened in the past. Here are more specific uses:
Completed actions in the past:
Events that began and ended at a specific time in the past
I went to Paris last summer.
She finished work at 5PM.
Past habits:
Actions that were done regularly in the past, but are no longer done
When I was a kid, I played soccer every day.
You don’t play soccer every day now.
My family stayed at the beach every summer when I was growing up.
Your family doesn’t go on these annual beach trips anymore.
Past states:
Conditions or situations that existed in the past
My mom was a high school English teacher.
She is either retired now or has a different job.
We lived in Canada for three years.
You don’t live in Canada anymore.
The conversation is about Pailin’s day at the Santa Monica Pier the past weekend. All of the past tense lines reflect #1, completed actions in the past.

sections.content:
## MISTAKE #1
Thai people sometimes use the wrong verb tense when past simple tense should be used.
Past simple tense can be intimidating to learn, since it requires memorization and practice, so learners often revert to a familiar tense, like present simple or present continuous.
However, native English speakers might get confused if you use the wrong verb tense when past simple tense should be used. For example:
Scenario #1 - Present simple tense vs. past simple tense
Imagine your friend calls you and asks why you didn’t go to his house party last night.
You didn’t go because you were tired last night, but if you tell him, ‘Sorry, I’m so tired,’ he will be confused, thinking that you’re tired right now, not that you were tired last night.
What you should say is:
Sorry, I was so tired.
Adding time markers, like ‘last night,’ can help indicate that you’re talking about the past, but try not to rely on them. It’s best to get in the habit of using past tense verbs.
Scenario #2 - Present continuous tense vs. past simple tense
Imagine your friend calls you and asks what you did last weekend.
If you say, ‘I’m visiting my grandparents,’ she will think that you were at your grandparents house over the weekend, and are still at your grandparents’ house now.
What you should say is:
I visited my grandparents.
The past tense ‘visited’ shows that the action is finished - you visited your grandparents and have returned home already.
## MISTAKE #2
Thai people sometimes use the incorrect sentence structure for negative past tense sentences, especially with irregular verbs:
[subject] didn’t [past tense verb]
I didn’t went to work today. [X]
He didn’t drove to the beach. [X]
They didn’t brought any food. [X]
Correct sentences
Remember that negative sentences must use the base form of the verb, since the word ‘didn’t’ already indicates past tense.
The correct sentences should be:
[subject] didn’t [verb]
I didn’t go to work today. [✓]
He didn’t drive to the beach. [✓]
They didn’t bring any food. [✓]

lesson.title: Level 4 Checkpoint
lesson.backstory: Pailin is having a job interview for a part-time position at Skylight Books, a bookstore near UCLA. Her interview is with Jerald, the store manager.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: Hi, Pailin. I’m Jerald, the store manager. Thanks for coming in today.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Nice to meet you! Thank you for having me.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: So, can you tell me a little about yourself?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Sure! So, I'm from Thailand, and I moved to LA a month ago. I’m a student at UCLA, and I’m studying Art History. I want to work here because I love books.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: That’s great! Do you have any work experience?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yes! I worked at a café last year. I took orders, helped customers, and used a cash register.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: That’s great to hear. What’s the last book you read?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I read The Night Circus. It was really interesting!

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: That’s a great book. So, this job is part-time. Can you work on weekends?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yes, I can! I'm free on the weekend, and I'm free after 2 on weekdays.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: Perfect. If we hire you, could you start next Monday, the 15th, at 3?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yes!

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: Great! We'll call you by Friday to tell you if you're hired. Do you have any questions?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yes! Where is the employee entrance?

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: It’s at the back of the store, on the left. Just go in through the gray door.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Got it! Thank you so much.

transcript.speaker: Jerald
transcript.line_text: You’re welcome! Have a great day!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: You too!
